data.text:
@MichaelBennet NO YOU DO!🤯🤯🤯
You’re a disgrace to your position!!

@MichaelBennet The second Obama administration from 2009 to 2016, his administration deported 2,749,706 individuals, averaging 343,713 deportations per year—the highest in 32 years. The Trump administration is following precedence.

@MichaelBennet Of the 375,000 immigrants expelled during the 6 years the program operated, more than 70% did not have crimes considered a national security threat, according to data from Syracuse University’s TRAC Center (Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse).

@MichaelBennet Under the Obama administration in 2012, a historic peak of deportations was reached, with an average of 1,123 deportations per day. Immigrant organizations to label Obama the “Deporter in Chief.”
@MichaelBennet He expanded the operations of the newly created ICE (2003) and intensified workplace raids. Deportations included both criminals and those accused of civil immigration violations.

@MichaelBennet The IIR and IRA of 1996 expanded deportation categories and reduced available legal defenses for the illegal immigrants. Following the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the Twin Towers in 2001, Bush prioritized deportations for national security reasons.

@MichaelBennet Data compiled and analyzed by Factchequeado shows that President Obama administration deported more immigrants than any other president in the last three decades. Under Clinton, deportations focused primarily on people with criminal backgrounds and immigration violations.
@MichaelBennet I hope and pray no more liberal idiots in Colorado
